The works of Euclid of Megara, the most acute philosopher and without controversy the prince of all mathematicians, translated by Campanus, the most faithful interpreter. These works, which previously, due to the deplorable fault of scribes, were so deformed by the most foul errors that we could scarcely recognize Euclid himself. Lucas Pacioli, a distinguished theologian, exceedingly rare in the highest knowledge of mathematical disciplines, with the most discerning judgment, cleansed and corrected them. He arranged one hundred and thirty-nine figures, which in other manuscripts were inverted and deformed, into correct symmetry and added many necessary ones. In many places, he also elucidated, explained, and illustrated the same work, which was difficult to understand, with very clear and most learned commentaries. Moreover, so that it might emerge more refined, Scipio Vegius of Milan, a man renowned in both languages, the medical art, and higher studies, provided his diligence and critique.
A. Paganius Paganinus was printing with the most elegant characters very accurately.
